concepts.title: Perfect Competition
concepts.desc: Many firms, identical products, no barriers to entry. Price takers. P = MR = MC in long run. Zero economic profit in LR.

concepts.title: Monopolistic Competition
concepts.desc: Many firms, differentiated products, low barriers. Downward-sloping demand. Zero economic profit in LR due to entry.

concepts.title: Oligopoly
concepts.desc: Few large firms, high barriers, interdependent pricing. Game theory applies. Nash equilibrium: each firm optimizes given others' choices.

concepts.title: Monopoly
concepts.desc: Single seller, unique product, very high barriers. Price maker. MR < P. Can earn economic profit in long run.

concepts.title: Profit Maximization
concepts.desc: All firms maximize profit where MR = MC. If P > ATC: economic profit. If AVC < P < ATC: operate at a loss. If P < AVC: shut down.

concepts.title: Economies of Scale
concepts.desc: LRAC decreases as output increases. Minimum efficient scale: output where LRAC is first minimized.

concepts.title: Concentration Measures
concepts.desc: N-firm ratio and HHI measure market concentration. HHI = sum of squared market shares. HHI > 2,500 = highly concentrated.

formulas.name: Profit Maximization
formulas.where: MR = marginal revenue, MC = marginal cost

decisions.question: Operate or Shut Down in Short Run?
use: Operate: P ‚â• AVC (covers variable costs, contributes to fixed costs)
Shut down: P < AVC (better to produce nothing)
avoid: Shutting down just because P < ATC ‚Äî firm should still operate if P > AVC

pitfalls: Economic profit includes opportunity costs ‚Äî zero economic profit doesn't mean accounting losses
In perfect competition: firms are price takers, demand curve is horizontal, P = MR
In monopoly: demand curve IS the firm's demand curve, MR < P (downward sloping)
Nash equilibrium: neither player can improve by unilaterally changing strategy

examples.title: Shutdown Decision
examples.problem: A firm has AVC = $8, ATC = $12, and price = $9. Should it operate?
examples.solution: Yes. P ($9) > AVC ($8), so the firm covers all variable costs and contributes $1/unit toward fixed costs. Shutting down would mean losing ALL fixed costs.

questions.question: In perfect competition, a firm's demand curve is:
questions.explanation: Perfectly competitive firms are price takers. They can sell any quantity at the market price, so their demand curve is horizontal.

questions.question: A firm should shut down in the short run when:
questions.explanation: Shut down when P < AVC because the firm cannot even cover variable costs. If AVC < P < ATC, keep operating ‚Äî the contribution covers some fixed costs.

questions.question: In a monopoly, marginal revenue is:
questions.explanation: For a monopolist, the demand curve slopes downward. To sell more, the firm must lower price on ALL units, so MR < P.

questions.question: An HHI of 3,000 indicates a market that is:
questions.explanation: HHI > 2,500 indicates a highly concentrated market. (1,500-2,500 = moderately concentrated; < 1,500 = unconcentrated.)

questions.question: In long-run equilibrium, which market structure(s) earn zero economic profit?
questions.explanation: Both perfect competition and monopolistic competition have free/low entry, so economic profits attract entrants until profits are zero. Monopolies and oligopolies can earn LR economic profits due to barriers.

concepts.title: Business Cycle Phases
concepts.desc: Expansion (trough to peak), Peak, Contraction/Recession (peak to trough), Trough. GDP growth fluctuates around trend.

concepts.title: Credit Cycles
concepts.desc: Expansion: easy credit, rising asset prices. Contraction: tightening, deleveraging. Credit cycles amplify business cycles.

concepts.title: Leading Indicators
concepts.desc: Signal future economic activity: stock prices, building permits, ISM new orders, yield curve slope, consumer expectations.

concepts.title: Coincident Indicators
concepts.desc: Move with the economy: industrial production, employment, personal income, manufacturing sales.

concepts.title: Lagging Indicators
concepts.desc: Follow the economy: unemployment rate, CPI, prime rate, average duration of unemployment, inventory/sales ratio.

decisions.question: How to identify the business cycle phase?
use: Leading indicators to forecast turning points
Coincident indicators to confirm current phase
Lagging indicators to confirm phase changes already occurred
avoid: Relying on a single indicator ‚Äî use composite measures

pitfalls: Stock market is a LEADING indicator ‚Äî it rises before the economy recovers
Unemployment is a LAGGING indicator ‚Äî it stays high even after recovery begins
Yield curve inversion is one of the strongest recession predictors
Credit cycles and business cycles are related but not identical

questions.question: Which of the following is a leading economic indicator?
questions.explanation: Building permits lead economic activity because construction starts before the broader economy expands.

questions.question: The unemployment rate is classified as a:
questions.explanation: Unemployment peaks after the recession has ended ‚Äî it's a lagging indicator that confirms past economic conditions.

questions.question: An inverted yield curve (short-term rates > long-term rates) has historically been a reliable predictor of recessions.
questions.explanation: Yield curve inversions have preceded most recessions in the US and many other countries, making it one of the strongest leading indicators.

concepts.title: Fiscal Policy Tools
concepts.desc: Government spending and taxation. Expansionary: increase spending / cut taxes. Contractionary: cut spending / raise taxes.

concepts.title: Fiscal Multiplier
concepts.desc: The amplified impact of government spending on GDP. Multiplier = 1 / (1 - MPC √ó (1-t)). Higher MPC = larger multiplier.

concepts.title: Balanced Budget Multiplier
concepts.desc: Equal increase in G and T increases output by 1. Spending multiplier > tax multiplier because MPC < 1.

concepts.title: Automatic Stabilizers
concepts.desc: Tax revenues and transfer payments that automatically adjust with the cycle. Reduce the amplitude of fluctuations without legislation.

concepts.title: Fiscal Stance
concepts.desc: Structural (cyclically adjusted) deficit measures true fiscal stance. Actual deficit includes cyclical components.

concepts.title: Ricardian Equivalence
concepts.desc: Theory: rational consumers save tax cuts to pay future taxes, neutralizing fiscal stimulus. Largely theoretical.

formulas.name: Fiscal Multiplier
formulas.where: MPC = marginal propensity to consume, t = tax rate

formulas.name: Tax Multiplier
formulas.where: Smaller in absolute value than spending multiplier

formulas.name: Balanced Budget Multiplier
formulas.where: Equal increase in G and T increases Y by exactly the amount of the increase

decisions.question: Expansionary vs Contractionary fiscal policy?
use: Expansionary (increase G, cut T) during recessions to boost demand
Contractionary (cut G, raise T) during overheating to cool demand
avoid: Pro-cyclical fiscal policy (expanding during booms, contracting during busts)

pitfalls: Implementation lag: fiscal policy takes time to legislate and implement
Crowding out: government borrowing may raise interest rates, reducing private investment
Spending multiplier > tax multiplier (because some of a tax cut is saved)
Structural deficit ‚â† actual deficit (remove cyclical component)

examples.title: Fiscal Multiplier
examples.problem: MPC = 0.8, tax rate = 25%. What is the fiscal multiplier?
examples.solution: Multiplier = 1/(1 - 0.8(1-0.25)) = 1/(1 - 0.6) = 1/0.4 = 2.5. A $1B increase in G raises GDP by $2.5B.

questions.question: If the MPC is 0.75 and the tax rate is 20%, the fiscal multiplier is closest to:
Crowding out occurs when:
options: Government borrowing raises interest rates and reduces private investment
Tax cuts are saved rather than spent
questions.explanation: Government borrowing competes with private borrowers for funds, pushing up interest rates and reducing private investment.

questions.question: The balanced budget multiplier equals:
questions.explanation: An equal increase in G and T still raises GDP by the amount of the increase because the spending multiplier > tax multiplier.

questions.question: Automatic stabilizers work by:
options: Automatically adjusting tax revenues and transfers over the business cycle
questions.explanation: Progressive taxes and transfer payments automatically expand/contract with the economy, smoothing the cycle without new legislation.

concepts.title: Central Bank Roles
concepts.desc: Lender of last resort, banker to government, monetary policy implementation, financial system regulation, payments system oversight.

concepts.title: Policy Rate
concepts.desc: The short-term interest rate set by the central bank (e.g., Fed Funds rate). Primary tool of conventional monetary policy.

concepts.title: Transmission Mechanism
concepts.desc: Policy rate ‚Üí market rates ‚Üí asset prices ‚Üí exchange rates ‚Üí expectations ‚Üí aggregate demand ‚Üí inflation/output.

concepts.title: Inflation Targeting
concepts.desc: Most central banks target 2% inflation. Provides anchor for expectations. Transparency and credibility are key.

concepts.title: Quantitative Easing (QE)
concepts.desc: Unconventional policy: central bank buys long-term assets to lower long-term rates when short-term rates are at zero (zero lower bound).

concepts.title: Central Bank Independence
concepts.desc: Operational independence reduces political pressure and inflation bias. Goal independence varies by country.

formulas.name: Fisher Equation
formulas.formula: Nominal Rate ‚âà Real Rate + Expected Inflation

formulas.name: Quantity Theory of Money
formulas.where: M = money supply, V = velocity, P = price level, Y = real output

formulas.name: Money Neutrality
formulas.where: In long run, money supply changes only affect prices, not real output

decisions.question: Expansionary vs Contractionary Monetary Policy?
use: Expansionary (lower rates, QE): recession, deflation risk, output below potential
Contractionary (raise rates): inflation above target, overheating economy
avoid: Keeping rates too low for too long (asset bubbles)

pitfalls: Monetary policy has shorter implementation lag than fiscal policy but longer impact lag
Liquidity trap: when rates are near zero, conventional policy becomes ineffective
Exchange rate channel: lower rates ‚Üí currency depreciation ‚Üí higher exports
Central bank credibility is crucial for inflation expectations anchoring

questions.question: The primary tool of conventional monetary policy is:
questions.explanation: The policy rate (e.g., Federal Funds rate) is the primary tool. Reserve requirements and QE are supplementary tools.

questions.question: Quantitative easing is typically used when:
options: The policy rate is already at or near zero
The government has a budget surplus
questions.explanation: QE is an unconventional tool used when the policy rate has hit the zero lower bound and conventional policy is exhausted.

questions.question: According to the quantity theory of money (MV=PY), if velocity (V) and real output (Y) are constant, an increase in money supply (M) leads to:
options: A proportional increase in real output
A proportional increase in the price level
questions.explanation: With V and Y constant, ŒîM = ŒîP. Money is neutral in the long run: changes in money supply only affect prices.

questions.question: Central bank independence is important because it:
options: Eliminates the need for fiscal policy
Reduces political pressure to pursue short-term inflationary policies
Allows the central bank to set fiscal policy
questions.explanation: Independence insulates the central bank from political pressure to finance government spending through money creation, which would cause inflation.

concepts.title: Geopolitical Risk
concepts.desc: Risk from political events, conflicts, sanctions, and policy changes that affect investment returns and economic activity.

concepts.title: Globalization Forces
concepts.desc: Trade liberalization, capital flows, technology diffusion, labor mobility. Benefits: efficiency, growth. Costs: inequality, dependency.

concepts.title: State Actors
concepts.desc: National governments with sovereignty. Non-state actors: international organizations (IMF, WTO, World Bank), NGOs, multinational corporations.

concepts.title: Tools of Geopolitics
concepts.desc: Military force, economic sanctions, trade agreements, soft power (culture, diplomacy), cyber capabilities.

concepts.title: Assessing Geopolitical Risk
concepts.desc: Identify threats, assess probability and impact, monitor signposts/escalation indicators, consider tail risks.

decisions.question: How to incorporate geopolitical risk?
use: Scenario analysis for different geopolitical outcomes
Country risk premiums in discount rates
Diversification across regions and geopolitical risk profiles

pitfalls: Geopolitical risks are often fat-tailed ‚Äî impact can be much larger than expected
Markets may be slow to price in gradual geopolitical deterioration
Globalization benefits are not evenly distributed, leading to backlash

questions.question: Which international organization primarily focuses on maintaining exchange rate stability and providing financial assistance to member countries?
questions.explanation: The IMF focuses on exchange rate stability, balance of payments assistance, and international monetary cooperation.

questions.question: Economic sanctions are best classified as a tool of:
questions.explanation: Sanctions use economic pressure (trade restrictions, asset freezes) to achieve political objectives.

concepts.title: Comparative Advantage
concepts.desc: A country should produce goods where its opportunity cost is lowest. Even if one country is better at everything, both benefit from trade.

concepts.title: Absolute Advantage
concepts.desc: Ability to produce a good using fewer resources. Less important than comparative advantage for determining trade patterns.

concepts.title: Trade Restrictions
concepts.desc: Tariffs (taxes on imports), quotas (quantity limits), export subsidies, voluntary restraints. All reduce efficiency.

concepts.title: Effects of Tariffs
concepts.desc: Higher domestic price, lower imports, domestic producers gain, consumers lose, government gains revenue, net deadweight loss.

concepts.title: Trade Agreements
concepts.desc: Free trade areas, customs unions, common markets, economic unions. Progressive levels of economic integration.

formulas.name: Terms of Trade
formulas.formula: ToT = Export Price Index / Import Price Index √ó 100
formulas.where: Improvement if ToT rises (exports become more valuable relative to imports)

decisions.question: Free trade vs Protectionism?
use: Free trade: maximizes global efficiency and consumer welfare
Protection: infant industries, national security, anti-dumping

pitfalls: Comparative advantage is about OPPORTUNITY COST, not absolute productivity
Tariffs help domestic producers but hurt consumers ‚Äî net effect is negative (deadweight loss)
Quotas are generally more harmful than tariffs because they eliminate price signals

examples.title: Comparative Advantage
examples.problem: Country A can produce 10 units of wine or 5 units of cloth. Country B can produce 6 units of wine or 4 units of cloth. Who has comparative advantage in wine?
examples.solution: A: opportunity cost of 1 wine = 0.5 cloth. B: opportunity cost of 1 wine = 0.67 cloth. Country A has comparative advantage in wine (lower opportunity cost).

questions.question: Comparative advantage is determined by:
questions.explanation: Comparative advantage is based on opportunity cost ‚Äî a country should specialize in goods where its opportunity cost is lowest, even if it's not the most efficient producer in absolute terms.

questions.question: A tariff on imports will most likely result in:
questions.explanation: Tariffs raise domestic prices, reducing consumer surplus. While producers and government gain, the net effect is a deadweight loss to society.

questions.question: A customs union differs from a free trade area in that it:
options: Eliminates all trade barriers between members
Has common external trade policies toward non-members
questions.explanation: A customs union adds a common external tariff policy on top of the free trade area's elimination of internal barriers.

modules.title: Capital Flows and the FX Market

concepts.title: Balance of Payments
concepts.desc: Current account (trade, income, transfers) + Capital account + Financial account = 0. CA deficit = net capital inflow.

concepts.title: Current Account
concepts.desc: Goods trade balance + services + primary income (investment) + secondary income (transfers). Deficit = spending > income.

concepts.title: Financial Account
concepts.desc: Direct investment, portfolio investment, other investment, reserve assets. Surplus = net capital inflow.

concepts.title: FX Market Structure
concepts.desc: Largest financial market ($7.5T/day). OTC, 24-hour, major participants: banks, central banks, corporates, speculators.

concepts.title: Exchange Rate Regimes
concepts.desc: Float (market-determined), Managed float (intervention), Fixed/Peg (tied to anchor), Currency board (strict peg with full reserves).

formulas.name: Balance of Payments Identity
formulas.formula: Current Account + Capital Account + Financial Account = 0
formulas.where: When one account is in deficit, another must be in surplus

decisions.question: Impact of current account deficit?
use: Currency depreciation pressure (more demand for foreign currency)
Must be financed by capital inflows (foreign investment)
avoid: Assuming all CA deficits are bad ‚Äî may reflect strong investment opportunities attracting capital

pitfalls: Current account deficit = financial account surplus (net capital inflow)
Capital flows can be volatile and lead to sudden stops/reversals
Reserve accumulation by central banks affects exchange rates

questions.question: If a country has a current account deficit, its financial account must show:
questions.explanation: By the BOP identity, a current account deficit must be offset by a financial account surplus (net capital inflows).

questions.question: A currency board differs from a conventional fixed exchange rate in that it:
options: Allows the exchange rate to float within bands
Requires full foreign reserve backing of the domestic money supply
Targets inflation instead of the exchange rate
questions.explanation: A currency board maintains a strict peg by holding foreign reserves equal to the entire domestic monetary base.

concepts.title: Exchange Rate Quotation
concepts.desc: Direct: domestic per foreign (e.g., 1.25 USD/EUR). Indirect: foreign per domestic. Price/Base convention: P/B.

concepts.title: Bid-Ask Spread
concepts.desc: Dealer buys at bid, sells at ask. Spread = ask - bid. Always buy high (ask) and sell low (bid) from YOUR perspective.

concepts.title: Cross Rates
concepts.desc: Exchange rate between two currencies derived through a third. A/C = (A/B) √ó (B/C).

concepts.title: Forward Exchange Rate
concepts.desc: Rate agreed today for exchange in the future. Forward premium: forward > spot. Forward discount: forward < spot.

concepts.title: Covered Interest Rate Parity
concepts.desc: Forward premium/discount reflects interest rate differential. Eliminates arbitrage between money markets and FX forwards.

concepts.title: Triangular Arbitrage
concepts.desc: Exploiting mispricing among three currency pairs. If cross rate differs from market rate, profit is possible.

formulas.name: Cross Rate
formulas.where: Multiply rates to find the cross rate

formulas.name: Forward Rate (CIP)
formulas.where: F = forward, S = spot, r = interest rate for the period

formulas.name: Bid-Ask with Cross Rates
formulas.where: Take bid of bid, ask of ask for cross

decisions.question: How to determine if arbitrage exists?
use: Compare calculated cross rate to market cross rate
If different, buy low and sell high through the triangle
Forward rate vs spot √ó interest rate differential for covered interest arbitrage
avoid: Ignoring transaction costs which may eliminate the arbitrage profit

pitfalls: Always check: are you buying or selling? You buy at ASK, sell at BID
Cross rates: cancel the common currency (e.g., USD cancels in EUR/USD √ó USD/JPY)
Forward points are usually quoted as pips/points, not full rates
Higher interest rate currency trades at a forward DISCOUNT (CIP)

examples.title: Forward Rate
examples.problem: Spot EUR/USD = 1.1000. US rate = 3%, Euro rate = 1%, 1-year forward?
examples.solution: F = 1.1000 √ó (1.03)/(1.01) = 1.1000 √ó 1.0198 = 1.1218. USD trades at forward discount (higher rate currency depreciates forward).

questions.question: If the USD/EUR spot rate is 1.10 and the 1-year US interest rate exceeds the EUR rate, the forward USD/EUR rate will be:
questions.explanation: Higher USD rate means USD trades at forward discount. F/S = (1+r_USD)/(1+r_EUR) > 1, so F > S. More USD per EUR forward.

questions.question: Given USD/EUR = 1.12 and USD/GBP = 1.31, the GBP/EUR cross rate is closest to:
A dealer's bid price for EUR/USD is 1.1050 and the ask is 1.1055. A client wanting to buy EUR would pay:
questions.explanation: The client buys EUR at the dealer's ask price (1.1055). The dealer buys at bid and sells at ask.

questions.question: Covered interest rate parity ensures that:
options: Real interest rates are equal across countries
The forward premium equals the interest rate differential
questions.explanation: CIP states that the forward premium (or discount) exactly offsets the interest rate differential, preventing riskless arbitrage.
